facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 412-414 of 1962 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 412-414 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment dated February 10, 1958 of the Assam High Court in Appeals from Original Decrees Nos. 10 to 21 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment dated February 10, 1958 of the Assam High Court in Appeals from Original Decrees Nos. 10 to 21 of 1953.

facts.text: Respondents are owners of a plot of land at Bharalumukh, Gauhati, on which stands a residential building.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in this appeal are owners of a plot of land at Bharalumukh, Gauhati, on which stands a residential building

facts.text: Government of India in 1943 requisitioned the land and building under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939 for defence forces.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939, the Government of India in 1943, requisitioned the land and the building for the use of the defence forces.

facts.text: Since the date of the requisition, the land and building continued in possession of the Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: Since the date of the requisition the land and the building continued in possession of the Government of India.

facts.text: Collector of Kamrup passed an order on February 9, 1949 for acquisition under s. 4 of the Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Kamrup passed an order on February 9, 1949 for acquisition of the land and building purporting to exercise powers under s. 4 of the Assam  Requisition and Acquisition  Act, 1948.

facts.text: At the time of the acquisition order on February 9, 1949, the requisition order by Government of India was subsisting.

anchor.surface_text: At this time the requisition order made by the Government of India was subsisting.

facts.text: By order dated August 4, 1949, the Collector requisitioned the land under s. 3 of the Assam Act 1948, effective from February 7, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter by order dated August 4, 1949 the Collector requisitioned the land in exercise of the power conferred by s. 3 of the Assam Act 1948, and ordered that the requisition do take effect from February 7, 1949.

facts.text: Collector assessed compensation payable to respondents under s. 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector assessed compensation payable to the respondents under s. 7 of the Act.

facts.text: Respondents applied for reference to Civil Court under s. 8 and challenged the authority of the Collector to acquire.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents applied for a reference to the Civil Court under s. 8 of the Act and simultaneously challenged the authority of the Collector to acquire the land in the manner he had done.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Gauhati held no valid acquisition but assessed compensation if valid.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Gauhati to whom the reference was made, held that there was no valid acquisition of the land and the building of the respondents. He, however, assessed compensation which would be payable to the respondents if the acquisition was valid.

facts.text: High Court of Assam confirmed the order that acquisition was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the High Court of Assam, the order passed by the Subordinate Judge, holding that the acquisition was invalid was confirmed.

facts.text: State of Assam filed appeal with certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam has filed this appeal with certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Acquisition was under Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948, not Land Acquisition Act 1894.

anchor.surface_text: Acquisition of the land and building belonging to the respondents was not made under the Land Acquisition Act I of 1894, but under the provisions of the Assam Land  Requisition and Acquisition  Act, 1948.

facts.text: Land was requisitioned under Rule 75-A of Defence of India Rules, 1939, not under s.3 of Assam Act.

anchor.surface_text: That order of requisition was passed not under s. 3 of the Assam Act, but under Rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939.

facts.text: Previous requisition under Defence of India Rules did not confer authority to acquire under s.4 of Assam Act.

anchor.surface_text: The previous requisition under the Defence of India Rules which was at the date of the order of acquisition outstanding could not confer any authority upon the Provincial Government of Assam to acquire the land belonging to the respondents under s. 4 of the Act.

facts.text: Acquisition order under s.4 was made before any requisition under s.3 of Assam Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, an order for acquisition of the land was made in the first instance and presumably because it was realized that the order was defective and irregular,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge assessed compensation assuming acquisition valid.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, assessed compensation which would be payable to the respondents if the acquisition was valid.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds acquisition illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, in our judgment, right in holding that the acquisition was illegal.

facts.text: Three appeals raise common question on validity of acquisition proceedings by Collector of Kamrup under s.4 Assam Act.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals raise a common question as to the validity of certain acquisition proceedings commenced by the Collector of Kamrup, State of Assam, under s. 4 of the Assam Land  Requisition and Acquisition  Act, 1948.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah J.
under s. 4 of the Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948.

issues.text: Whether the acquisition proceedings commenced under s. 4 of the Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948 are valid?

anchor.surface_text: question as to the validity of certain acquisition proceedings companymenced by the Collector of Kamrup, State of Assam, under s. 4 of the Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948.

issues.text: Whether the power to acquire land under s. 4 of the Assam Act can be exercised without prior requisition under s. 3 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: The power to acquire land under s. 4 may, it is plain from a bare perusal of sub-s. 1 , be exercised where the land has been requisitioned under s. 3 and number otherwise.

issues.text: Whether a prior requisition under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939 qualifies as a requisition under s. 3 of the Assam Act for the purpose of acquisition under s. 4?

anchor.surface_text: That order of requisition was passed number under s. 3 of the Assam Act, but under Rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939. The previous requisition under the Defence of India Rules which was at the date of the order of acquisition outstanding could number confer any authority upon the Provincial Government of Assam to acquire the land belonging to the respondents under s. 4 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether a subsequent requisition under s. 3 of the Assam Act can validate an earlier acquisition order under s. 4 made without prior requisition?

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, an order for acquisition of the land was made in the first instance and presumably because it was realized that the order was defective and irregular, it was sought to be rectified by passing an order on August 4, 1949, requisitioning the land with effect from February 7, 1949. By this expedient, an illegal order of acquisition could number be validated.

issues.text: Whether s. 11 of the Assam Act bars challenge to the validity of the acquisition order?

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that notwithstanding the illegality in the acquisition, the order of acquisition was saved by s. 11 of the Assam Act, which provides Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, no decision or order made in exercise of any power conferred by or under this Act shall be called in question in any Court. It cannot, however, be said that the order passed under s. 4 acquiring the land of the respondents was made in exercise of the power conferred by or under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquisition under s.4 invalid without prior requisition under s.3; Defence of India Rules requisition does not qualify; subsequent requisition cannot validate; s.11 does not bar challenge.

holdings.text: The power to acquire land under s. 4 may, it is plain from a bare perusal of sub-s. 1, be exercised where the land has been requisitioned under s. 3 and not otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The power to acquire land under s. 4 may, it is plain from a bare perusal of sub-s. 1 , be exercised where the land has been requisitioned under s. 3 and number otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.4(1) expressly conditions acquisition power on prior requisition under s.3.

holdings.text: By this expedient, an illegal order of acquisition could not be validated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquisition order under s.4 made before s.3 requisition; later backdated requisition cannot cure defect.

holdings.text: The previous requisition under the Defence of India Rules which was at the date of the order of acquisition outstanding could not confer any authority upon the Provincial Government of Assam to acquire the land belonging to the respondents under s. 4 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.11 bars only orders made in exercise of powers under the Act; invalid acquisition order lacks such authority.
